column1: Frisco is a city in Collin and Denton Counties in Texas
column2: part of the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex
column3: and is about 25 miles (40 km) from both Dallas Love Field and Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport. The city population was 116
column4: 989 at the 2010 census. The 2019 census estimate placed the city population at 200
column5: 490.Frisco was the fastest-growing city in the United States in 2017
column6: and also the fastest-growing city in the nation from 2000 to 2009. In the late 1990s
column7: the northern DFW suburban development tide hit the northern border of Plano and spilled into Frisco
column8: sparking rapid growth into the 2000s. Like many of the cities in the northern suburbs of Dallas
column9: Frisco serves as a bedroom community for professionals who work in DFW. Since 2003
column10: Frisco has received the designation Tree City USA by the National Arbor Day Foundation.

column1: When the Dallas area was being settled by American pioneers
column2: many of the settlers traveled by wagon trains along the Shawnee Trail. This trail became the Preston Trail
column3: and later
column4: Preston Road. With all of this activity
column5: the community of Lebanon was founded along this trail
column6: and was granted a U.S. post office in 1860. In 1902
column7: a line of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway was being built through the area
column8: and periodic watering stops were needed along the route for the steam locomotives. The current settlement of Lebanon was on the Preston Ridge
column9: and was too high in elevation
column10: so the watering stop was placed about 4 miles (6 km) to the west on lower ground. A community grew around this train stop. Some residents of Lebanon actually moved their houses to the new community on logs. The new town was originally named Emerson
column11: but the U.S. Postal Service rejected the name as being too similar to another town in Texas. In 1904
column12: the town's residents chose "Frisco City" in honor of the St. Louis–San Francisco Railway. This name was later shortened to Frisco.

column1: Most of Frisco is within the Frisco Independent School District (Frisco ISD)
column2: with some parts of the city extending into the Lewisville Independent School District
column3: Little Elm Independent School District
column4: and Prosper Independent School District.  Lewisville ISD and Prosper ISD each have one elementary school in Frisco
column5: while all other public schools within the city limits are Frisco ISD schools.  (Prosper ISD will open a middle school in Frisco in 2019 and a high school in 2020.)

column2: 17 middle schools and 42 elementary schools. Most of Frisco ISD schools are within the Frisco city limits
column3: but some are located in adjacent suburbs
